92.title: Moon Mullins
92.author: by Frank Willard.
92.series: Jan. 11, 1951) "Cut His Ears Off a Piece at at Time"*
notes: Summary: Willie takes off when he overhears Lady Plushbottom and Mamie discuss torture.

93.title: Moon Mullins
93.author: Ferd Johnson
93.appears_in: reproduced on p. 125 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Alone on the course, Winston Plushbottom nudges his ball off the edge of the 18th hole when his 100th stroke is a fraction short; then he can't bring himself to lie to other golfers.

94.title: Moon Mullins
94.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: At the 19th hole, Lord Plushbottom proposes a toast to Scotland, and the inventors of golf and scotch.

95.title: Moon Mullins
95.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Mamie wants to know why their lawn can't look as good as the neighbor's, and Willy goes next door to ask him to let it go to seed.

96.title: Moon Mullins
96.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Lord P. transfers his skill at the golf course to hoeing the garden.

97.title: Moon Mullins
97.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: From his hammock, Lord P. fights air pollution by not mowing the lawn, and Lady P. ends up mowing it.

98.title: Moon Mullins
98.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Plushie has trouble keeping his eye on the ball after the 3rd ricochet.

99.title: Moon Mullins
99.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Kayo's playing taxi with roller skates and a steering wheel, and Willie calls him in for lunch.

100.title: Moon Mullins
100.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Lady P. puts Lord P. in charge of everything outside that's green and shaggy.

101.title: Moon Mullins
101.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: The cooks at a cookout can't agree on how much Tabasco to use.

102.title: Moon Mullins
102.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Kayo shows Teddy his dog Scratch, and Teddy says Kayo's almost out of dog.

103.title: Moon Mullins
103.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Scratch has learned to beg from dog food commercials.

104.title: Moon Mullins
104.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Plushbottom hits his golf ball straight, and the caddy suggests he must have put some slice on his hook.

105.title: Moon Mullins
105.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Mamie, the cook in a diner, gets a birthday present from her customers. She says she'll bust some heads if it's a cookbook.

106.title: Moon Mullins
106.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Scratch snapped at Lord Plushbottom's leg because he forgot the dog food.

107.title: Moon Mullins
107.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: The doctor asks Lord Plushbottom not to play golf on Tuesdays, as he finds too many divots on Wednesday mornings.

108.title: Moon Mullins
108.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Emmy says she's going to plant bulbs, and Kayo thinks she's blown a fuse.

109.title: Moon Mullins
109.author: Ferd and Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Kayo has some advice for his best friend Scratch: Stick to your doggie kibble and forget the stuff they serve me.

110.title: Moon Mullins
110.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Moon can't get a loan to expand his cab company, because they asked for collateral and he had to show them his taxi.

111.title: Moon Mullins
111.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Plushbottom's been working a double shift, and comes home so tired he hangs his stuff on Emmy instead of on the hat rack.

112.title: Moon Mullins
112.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: From his hammock, Lord P. says the lawn's turning brown is a nice change from all that green.

113.title: Moon Mullins
113.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Plushbottom sees the golf carts as too expensive to rent, so he takes Kayo's bike.

114.title: Moon Mullins
114.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Barbara prefers watching TV to going out with Moon, because she can turn the TV off.

115.title: Moon Mullins
115.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Kayo hoes in the garden, then tracks it indoors while asking for his pay.

116.title: Moon Mullins
116.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Lord P. is teed off, lost his third ball, and to his surprise the sneaky thing is right by the green.

117.title: Moon Mullins
117.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Geese fly south and Plushie sadly puts his clubs away for the winter.

118.title: Moon Mullins
118.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
118.series: Dec. 7, 1988) "The Other Side of the Fence"
notes: Summary: Brandishing her rolling pin, Mamie tells Willie to push the lawnmower, but she doesn't say where. He heads for Teddy's Tavern.

119.title: Moon Mullins
119.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: The teacher says the ninth planet is named Pluto, but the student would have preferred "Snoopy."

120.title: Moon Mullins
120.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Joke has a checklist of things he needs before he goes out to drive the cab.

121.title: Moon Mullins
121.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: The portions in Plushbottom's economical cookbook leave the diners hungry, because it was published in 1932.

122.title: Moon Mullins
122.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Plushie comes home tired, and the boarders have a scare thinking Emmy might be cooking dinner.

123.title: Moon Mullins
123.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Plushbottom may have to give up golf because his clubs are wrapped around trees.

124.title: Moon Mullins
124.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Plushbottom spends $95.32 in one hour of grocery shopping.

125.title: Moon Mullins
125.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Plushbottom's golf game went well.

126.title: Moon Mullins
126.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Emmy trips on a skateboard, and asks Moon to say a few choice words, since he knows more of them.

127.title: Moon Mullins

notes: Summary: The rent is due, so the bar puts out free salted peanuts.

203.title: The Moon Child
notes: The Moon Child / by Jean Claude Forest ; edited by Sean Kelly ; translated by Valerie Marchant. -- New York : Heavy Metal Communications, 1978. -- 51 p. : ill. ; 32 cm. -- (Barbarella) -- Begins with an eight page summary of the adventures of Barbarella in comics and film, including a description of an album that appeared in French between the two albums that we have seen in English. -- "The Moon Child" originally appeared in English in six consecutive issues of Heavy Metal , v. 1, no. 11 (Feb. 1978) to v. 2, no. 3 (July 1978). -- Genres: Science fiction, erotic. -- Call no.: PN6747.F64 M613 1978

Summary: In a nightmare, Barbarella arrives at a laboratory where a cosmonaut named Browningwell is in a box in a kind of artificial sleep. Scientists recruit Barbarella to join him in his dream, in a separate box, with the goal of waking him up to find out what great secret he may be hiding. When she encouters him, he is working on a masterpiece. By way of explanation, he says that "the race which people called 'French' has become the master race, and masterpices are henceforth on a cosmic scale!" In other words, he's a freedom-fighter building a planet for the Brotherhood of the Children of the Cosmos, in competition with the evil Nevil Level of the Universal Workers' Guild, who is building a cosmic cathedralbank that produces artificial gold. The prize is a planetary system. Browningwell's masterpiece is being assembled in a workshop, but a machine embodying the Thingimibob Transfer Principle projects whatever Browningwell makes to a million times its size out in space. Nevil Level's brother Charlie Chisel attacks and damages Browningwell's masterpiece, and all seems lost. Then, with Barbarella as his inspiration, Browningwell starts working furiously again. She is resentful of her treatment by the Brotherhood, which does not consider women as creative, and asks for a vacation of 300 days on the fertility planet Gyn-Gyn, seducing Browningwell vigorously on the trip there. After 300 days he returns to find they have a son, whom they name Little Foxy. Returning to the workshop, she finds he is making a new masterpiece, a Barbarelliform moon holding a shining globe, which he calls "Science Lighting the World." Barbarella isn't quite happy that the giant effigy shows her naked and on her back, but that's art for you. News comes that Nevil Level's masterpiece is almost done, so Browningwell goes to a universe where time passes slower to finish. They return a few hours later, on Little Foxy's fourth birthday, with a complete model of the moon ready for the Thingimibob Transfer. The Council of the Brotherhood, pushed by a silversmith named Spoonlove, decides it isn't quite enough and without Browningwell's knowledge starts a process whereby the moon will become living flesh, and Barbarella will become a statue. Barbarella soon loses her senses of smell and hearing. Browningwell blows a hole in the model to stop them. Little Foxy, trying to get help for his mother, crawls into the hole and gets transferred to the real moon. Spoonlove is revealed as an agent provocateur (the cathedral bank can't really produce artificial gold) and what's more, he's Nevil Level himself. A dash into space to rescue Little Foxy starts a battle with ray guns all over and around the naked, semi-alive, moon-sized body of Barbarella. When Nevil Level and his cronies are all dead, Barbarella and Browningwell wake in their boxes and realize it was all a dream. Then they go out of the laboratory and find Little Foxy telling his friends about them.

This summary is from European Comics in English Translation (Jefferson, NC : McFarland & Company, 2002). Used with permission.
